title: OP Low Gear/High RPM issue on 2020 Lexus RX 350
body:
**Describe the bug**
Most notably at freeway speeds, engaging OP results in two downshifts shortly thereafter and an unnecessarily high RPM until disengaged or upon encountering a vehicle within following distance intervention.  Manual or stock cruise control driving (OP disabled) over the same stretch of road at the same speed does not result in this low gear/high RPM behavior.  As indicated by several Discord posts, this same behavior is also evident on other RX’s of earlier year models as well.

**How to reproduce or log data**
Engage OP at freeway speeds and observe downshifts/high RPMs (2500-4000) shortly thereafter.  Alternatively, accelerate to freeway speeds with OP engaged and observe high RPMs.  Disengage OP and observe the car promptly upshift and RPMs return to a normal freeway cruising range 1500-1800.

**Expected behavior**
Engaging OP or using it at freeway speeds should not result in downshifts and maintaining a highly inefficient DOUBLING of engine RPM just because OP is in use.  OP long should result in mimicking driving the car manually at speed or as the stock cruise control does on the freeway—overdrive gear and 1500-1800 RPM.

**Device/Version information**
- Dongle ID:  3a5c5101bd71ad5d
- Route:  3a5c5101bd71ad5d|2020-08-30--13-12-43
- Timestamp:  Reference multiple engagements/disengagements starting 2 minutes into the clip.
- Version:  release2 v0.7.8
- Car make/model:  2020 Lexus RX 350

**Additional context**
There appears to be a discrepancy between UI_SET_SPEED and SPEED (actual) that could be causing the problem.  @nelsonjchen developed a “set speed scaling” solution that does resolve the problem.  Reference his comment to @cecnic1989’s PR about the same issue:  https://github.com/commaai/opendbc/pull/279#issuecomment-679826539

When implementing @nelsonjchen’s solution and adjusting the speed scale factor to 0.974 (which represents the 2.6% difference between UI_SET_SPEED and SPEED on my vehicle at approximately 65 mph), the low gear/high RPM issue is completely resolved.  Reference route 3a5c5101bd71ad5d|2020-08-30--14-30-28 where over the same stretch of freeway the correct gear is maintained and the RPM stays within 1500-1800 except for a brief period of road surface incline and then it promptly upshifts and returns to the normal RPM cruising range.

OP code needs to be modified so that the speed discrepancy between what is set and what the actual speed is does not trigger inappropriate OP long commands that cause undesired downshifts and high RPMs that result in considerable inefficiency and make OP use on the freeway impractical.  This modification could be in the form of a “Set Speed Scale” menu interface as proposed by @nelsonjchen (which I support) or fundamental changes to OP code on a per-vehicle basis to account for the speed discrepancies.  In any case, a change is needed to correct this undesired behavior.  Thanks.

title: Comma Two Fails to Update
body:
**Describe the bug**

My comma two says I need to connect to the internet immediately to check for an update when it's already connected to the internet (wifi from my apartment).

**How to reproduce or log data**

I'm not sure where logs are written, but I can reproduce this by manually modifying the date in the `/data/params/d/LastUpdateTime` file. I can also see a count of 85 failed updates in the `/data/params/d/UpdateFailedCount`.

title: 2021 Rav4 Prime gets CAN Error even after the fingerprint is added (STEERING_LKA and PRE_COLLISION seems to have a different checksum scheme?)
body:
**Describe the bug**

2021 Rav4 Prime gets CAN Error even [after the fingerprint is added](https://github.com/commaai/openpilot/pull/2018). 

[We've checked the setup against another Rav4 and the harness and C2 do not show the same error message and believe the hardware to be sound.](https://discordapp.com/channels/469524606043160576/524327905937850394/749377789723148368)

We get this error:

![](https://media.discordapp.net/attachments/524327905937850394/748711512910069788/FQpE1sjDSO17Yy-SrAZ68cQiSZd-oakrEjM6gqwBML7pQIa3EmaBIKIft8pEGfu9mtpLqI_c6ULaw2OxssZq0MrZoWvS6rwgzwyY.png)

**How to reproduce or log data**

With a known-good Harness + C2 setup installed in the Rav4 Prime, checkout this branch on the C2: https://github.com/nelsonjchen/openpilot/tree/rav4_prime_fw @ commit 640ae8b

Start the Rav4 Prime.

**Expected behavior**

No CAN Error or `CHECKSUM FAIL` error in `tmux`.

**Device/Version information (please complete the following information):**
 - Device: Comma 2
 - Dongle ID: 54bb533aec9ff844
 - Route: 54bb533aec9ff844\|2020-08-29--13-31-50
 - Timestamp: 158433520979974 from logs is when the error message is printed to the screen.
 - Version: https://github.com/nelsonjchen/openpilot/tree/rav4_prime_fw @ 640ae8b0b56a52a4eef662192967546e660c66a0
 - Car make/model: 2021 RAV4 Prime (VIN ends in 002147) 

**Additional context**

I've been helping matty#8553 on Discord add support for his 2021 Rav4 Prime to openpilot. Many others and I thought this was as simple as adding the [fingerprint for the TSS2 Rav4 Prime to OP](https://github.com/commaai/openpilot/pull/2018). This turns out to not be the case. 

After reproduction, we have SSH'd into the C2 and taken a look at `tmux a`, we see `CHECKSUM FAIL` spam:

![](https://media.discordapp.net/attachments/524327905937850394/749388683123097740/Screen_Shot_2020-08-29_at_3.02.57_PM.png?width=1237&height=911)

Looking at Cabana, it seems that `STEERING_LKA` is now 8 bytes in size up from 5 bytes in the past and that PRE_COLLISION IS size 8 up from 7.

I took a look at `STEERING_LKA` and tried the existing checksum algorithm [in a scratch-program, I implemented Toyota's checksum per the IOActive document to the last value and seeing if that pre-existing approach works for the RAV4 Prime's 8 byte `STEERING_LKA`. My unit tests work for my Corolla 2020's data. It doesn't for the 2021 Rav4 Prime's data and they don't match.](https://github.com/nelsonjchen/toyota_checksum_2020_scratch/blob/8422bd3b4b7770391e940d31202b8129fdebcb02/src/lib.rs#L97-L108)

The last four bytes for `STEERING_LKA` are rapidly changing. 

![high_entropy](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/5363/91650158-ed5f5880-ea30-11ea-9b07-6e3dca7f8f83.gif)

I haven't taken a look at `PRE_COLLISION` other than noticing the size change. Using the existing algorithm on a value here doesn't seem to work either.

Unfortunately, I've hit the limits of what I can do right now. I think Toyota has changed the checksum scheme or something for `STEERING_LKA` and `PRE_COLLISION`. 

I am not the owner of this 2021 Rav4 Prime, matty#8553 on Discord is. 

Please reach out to matty#8553 if you need him to perform some diagnosis. If there may be something out of his depth and Comma staff or someone from the community is not available or willing to help him through the "boring" diagnosis parts such as setup/SSH/forks/etc, let me know and I will be happy to help walk matty#8553 through those tasks.

title: Fix comma two detection as dos
[GM] Cannot resume after stop
body:
**Describe the bug**

#1729 added a change to show an alert (`EventName.belowSteerSpeed`) when `vEgo < minSteerSpeed`. That change finally got merged into a release (0.7.7) this week and I got to test it out. There is a potential unintended consequence of that change:

1) The alert when stopped that used to show "Stopped. Press resume to resume" is no longer showing when stopped.
2) Pressing resume from a stop doesn't do anything
3) `belowSteerSpeed` alert is always displayed when `vEgo < minSteerSpeed`, regardless of stopped status.

**How to reproduce or log data**

Come to a complete stop. Press resume.

**Expected behavior**

1) "Stopped. Press resume to resume" alert should display.
2) Pressing resume should resume.

**Device/Version information (please complete the following information):**
 - Device: EON
 - Dongle ID: N/A
 - Route: N/A
 - Version: 0.7.7
 - Car make/model: Chevy Volt

**Additional context**

Maybe we should change it to show the "Stopped" alert when at 0mph, instead of the `belowSteerSpeed` message.
IMO, it doesn't make sense to display the "steer unavailable" message at 0mph anyway, since we don't need to steer when stopped.

title: HKG Resume Bug
body:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/33460783/84581707-2b45cc80-adb2-11ea-8e36-727acdce838d.png)


When using stock HKG SCC there is a 1 in 20 chance the ECU will fault and cancel SCC when OP sends resume command. It has come to my attention that this usually happens after OP sends a resume command multiple times but the lead vehicle creeps within 3.7 meters and the SCC logic does not resume because of this. I would try modifying the code so that it remains as is, but does not attempt to resume unless the lead vehicle distance is reported as more than 3.7 meters and increasing. This may help remedy the issue although it may not be the root cause. Sending resume at and below 3.7 Meters is pointless as SCC will not resume anyway.

Example logic:

ACC_ObjDist

Stationary at X.X climbs to 3.7 <--- DO NOT RESUME

Stationary at X.X climbs to 3.8 <--- SEND RESUME PAST 3.7 (3.8)

Stationary at 4.8 <--- DO NOT RESUME

Stationary at 4.8 then climbs <--- SEND RESUME ON INCREASE (Greater than 3.7)

title: Don't follow cell network automatic time while onroad
body:
🎵 If I could turn back time
🎵 If I could find a way
🎵 I'd take back all those words that hurt you
🎵 And then I'd never turn back time while onroad ever again because no good can come of it

openpilot itself is very good (but not perfect) about using monotonic since-boot time tracking. However, time slips still do weird things to Android, they create difficulties when doing forensic log analysis, and I can't totally rule out some nexus with #1162. We can still use it when offroad.

Enable/disable: `settings put global auto_time [0|1]`

title: Intermittent temp steering faults for Toyota
body:
Some users are seeing intermittent temp steering faults on sharp turns for Toyota. A solution in openpilot was attempted in #1256 but not yet accepted.

It's been reported that driving in all-output safety mode makes the problem go away. This is not yet fully verified, and obviously that's not a good daily-drive configuration, but it's of diagnostic interest. It tells us the Panda safety mode may be discarding messages for torque level or ramp-rate violations, and the temp steering faults from the steering rack could be a consequence of those missing messages.

If this can be verified, it means we need to find and fix two issues:

1) We have airspace between what OP can send and what Panda safety is willing to pass
2) We have airspace between what OP can send and Panda regression testing is exercising

If you're experiencing this issue, please add a comment with a drive segment log, and I'll take a look early next week.

@wocsor -  fbd011384db5e669|2020-06-04--15-46-08--11
@ShaneSmiskol - ?

title: Relay malfunction doesn't trigger warning in openpilot
body:
When the relay in the panda is not switching correctly, nothing will be sent out. However, currently this is not shown anywhere in openpilot, and it looks like everything is functioning normally.

Most of the code is already there. We just need to put the relay in the panda health packet, and correctly build the health.faults list in boardd.

title: Fix system lags related to cellular connection -- $1000 bounty
body:
Very rarely we have seen complete system lockup of about 0.2 to 1 second. See for example the time between packets in this plot:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1314752/75200790-81b3d000-571b-11ea-80fd-e4d41f3ec46d.png)

Usually this causes a CAN error out of nowhere and a disengagement. One user reported that it always happens at the same point in his commute when he loses cellular connection.

My theory is that it is related to cell signal dropping or switching between towers, this is doing something in the kernel that locks up the whole system until it's done.

 - $200 for a reliable way to reproduce
 - $800 for a description of the root cause and merged pull request that fixes this issue.

title: Sensors Init Failure -- $1000 Bounty
body:
After some reboots, the gyro does not initialize correctly, forcing the user to reboot to get the gyro back. Seems to affect the LeEco more than the OnePlus.

The alert this will fix is "No Data from Device Sensors" "Reboot your Device"

$1000 for a description of the root cause and merged pull request that fixes this issue.

title: ACC can be bypassed on Toyota by holding down cruise on/off button
body:
**Describe the bug**
ACC can by bypassed on Toyota. Openpilot allows engagement when ACC is disabled. This bug was already fixed on Honda https://github.com/commaai/openpilot/pull/770 

**How to reproduce or log data**
Press and hold down the cruise on/off button. ACC will be disabled and the car will switch to non-adaptive cruise control. Press set to engage. Openpilot will control steering, but ACC will not function.

**Expected behavior**
Openpilot should not be allowed to be engaged without ACC.

**Device/Version information:**
 - Device: EON Gold
 - Version: 0.7.2
 - Car make/model: 2018 Toyota Prius Prime

**Additional context**
This loophole has been tested on the three major types of Toyota: DSU connected and disconnected, Nodsu, and TSS 2.0

I suspect that this signal could be used to detect when non-adaptive cruise control is enabled:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/44124235/74376390-04e63500-4db0-11ea-8fa8-10bacfcb876b.png)

I believe CRUISE_CONTROL_STATE 1.0 is non-adaptive cruise control. This could be used to detect that state.

I have demonstrated using the loophole in this drive https://my.comma.ai/cabana/?route=b29e3bc918751697%7C2020-02-12--12-04-27&exp=1613076855&sig=Z3uBeA6LE4ovlWgKaSEomaR6j8KdcUViZ8176dMW6Jk%3D&max=13&url=https%3A%2F%2Fchffrprivate-vzn.azureedge.net%2Fchffrprivate3%2Fv2%2Fb29e3bc918751697%2F1fadd736273c29c679b40bab0ff87058_2020-02-12--12-04-27

title: Disable LDW when not calibrated
Importing selfdrive.version writes to .git
body:
Importing selfdrive.version writes to the .git directory. Probably due to:
`        subprocess.check_call(["git", "update-index", "--refresh"])`

Writing to disk during the startup process could cause disk corruption on the comma two if were to unplug it during this write operation.

Writing to the `.git` directory also causes the updater to reinitalize the overlay.

title: 0.7.1 panda subaru safety has a logic bug which causes eyesight to fault on engagement
body:
**Describe the bug**
Subaru RX check in panda safety includes both preglobal and global platform can messages which causes eyesight to fault when openpilot is engaged

https://github.com/commaai/openpilot/blob/devel/panda/board/safety/safety_subaru.h#L14
```
AddrCheckStruct subaru_rx_checks[] = {
  {.addr = {0x119, 0x371}, .bus = 0, .expected_timestep = 20000U},
  {.addr = {0x240, 0x144}, .bus = 0, .expected_timestep = 50000U},
};
```
Global platform models have only 0x119 and 0x240 and preglobal platform models have 0x371 and 0x144. I think Subaru RX check fails because it requires that all 4 exist.

For a temporary workaround, I disabled addr_check and addr_check_len in subaru_hooks and after reflashing panda eyesight did not fault when openpilot is engaged:
https://github.com/commaai/openpilot/blob/devel/panda/board/safety/safety_subaru.h#L154

**How to reproduce or log data**
Engage openpilot using Eyesight SET button

**Expected behavior**
Eyesight should not fault when openpilot is engaged

**Device/Version information (please complete the following information):**
 - Device: EON
 - Version: 0.7.1
 - Car make/model: Subaru Crosstrek 2018

**Additional context**
Add any other context about the problem here.

title: Pedal overshoot (17 Corolla)
body:
I took a drive on the stock Toyota pedal tuning (albeit not on stock openpilot, but there were no leads so it was just maintaining set speed) and this is how my velocity and set speed relate:

![Screenshot_411](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/25857203/71516528-0cd52e80-286f-11ea-90fb-1fc9d1fb257d.png)

The time that set speed was set to 70+, I was driving on open road without any major hills. The maximum it overshot was 3 or 4 mph at 75 mph, while it was mostly 1 or 2 mph overshoot. It overshoots even if it's a slow acceleration, it continues to give gas when above by around 1.5 mph then it figures out that it needs to slow down after a second or two.

I really have no experience tuning PID or PI loops, so I have no real solution. But if the raw data can be useful to anyone who's more experienced, let me know.

title: Learned angle offset not accurate
body:
**Describe the bug**
The average angle offset that openpilot dumps into LiveParameters never seems to be accurate, which I think has been the cause of my lane hugging issues since I got openpilot about a year ago. Since my car had 50,000 miles put on it in the course of the year prior to me buying it, I assume it developed some wheel angle offset, or misalignment with the tires causing all this. I first tried messing with the camera offset, then different mounting positions and angles only for nothing to help my left lane hugging.
My `angleOffsetAverage` value right now is `-0.080168674153025768`, and it never seems to stray too far from that value. However when on Arne's fork a few months ago, I noticed that when I or openpilot is driving on a straight highway, my steering wheel is at around -1 to -2 degrees (pointed to the right). I even notice myself naturally offsetting the wheel to the right slightly in order to go straight. After adding ~1.5 degrees in `latcontrol_pid` to my current angle_steers (so that -1.5 is 0 degrees), my left lane hugging around left curves is nearly non-existent.

**Device/Version information (please complete the following information):**
 - Device: EON Gold
 - Version: 0.6.6
 - Car make/model Toyota Corolla 2017 LE

title: Waiting Toyota dash display
body:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/844102/69175415-059a6280-0b04-11ea-8b04-1beeaded08e7.png)

**Describe the bug**
If you have ever seen this dispaly before above. It is because you have probably a Toyota hybrid and you have come to a complete stop and now you can not use the resume button anymore to up the speed

**How to reproduce or log data**
Grab a rav4 hybrid. Take out the dsu and try stop and go.

**Expected behavior**
A clear and concise description of what you expected to happen.

** Device/Version information (please complete the following information):**
 - Device: EON/EON Gold
 - Version: 0.6.6
 - Car make/model: Toyota Hybrid 2017 maybe more Hybrids effected

**Additional context**
This state arises because of disengage on gas. If you would be able to tap the gas pedal after a stand still you would be allowed to up the set speed by using the stock. 

A general safety question would be is it safe to disengage lateral control on gas or brake? Should we not consider using the same approach as lateral for longitudinal. You can help open pilot along by giving more gas when needed or more brake when needed without disengaing. It would be crazy if with every lateral input you would loose longitudinal control and so I would propose for a change in the safety rules.

It was working fine with the safety lock on 0.6.5

title: Delay between audio Alert and Visual
body:
**Describe the bug**
Sometimes the audible alert for the RED screen comes a few 100 ms after the visual display.

**How to reproduce or log data**
By me it is when I put in reverse gear while openpilot is engaged.

**Expected behavior**
The audible alert should be just as fast to start playing as the visual alert is to display.

** Device/Version information (please complete the following information):**
 - Device:  EON
 - Version: 0.6.5 when on devel
 - Car make/model: 2018 Rav4 Hybrid

title: OpenPilot is still engaged after car shuts off
body:
**Describe the bug**
Prius 2018 i-Tech
OpenPilot sometimes keep itself engaged after the car is fully shutted-off. OpenPilot no longer communicates with the car if the car is restarted and the car will display DSU errors.

**How to reproduce or log data**
Shut off car with OpenPilot in "ready to engage" mode

**Expected behavior**
EON should display ride completed

** Device/Version information (please complete the following information):**
 - Device: EON
 - Version: 0.6.5
 - Car make/model: Prius 2018 i-Tech

**Additional context**
Add any other context about the problem here.
Photo: 
![IMG_20191017_161313](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/12470297/67000049-d1a5d900-f122-11e9-8dc5-6c47bdacff0c.jpg)

title: When approaching a fork in the road
body:
**Describe the bug**
If the model is able to do lane changes then it should also be able to know which way to take when a road forks.

**How to reproduce or log data**
At the moment it is a hit and miss. Sometimes right sometimes left, sometimes even worse is straight into the barrier.

**Expected behavior**
The model should favour the right lane of the right blinker is on momentarily or favour the left lane if the blinker is on momentarily.

** Device/Version information (please complete the following information):**
 - Device: all
 - Version: n/a
 - Car make: all

**Additional context**
Could probably be coded like I explained above but maybe you guys have a better idea how to use the model to decide which way to go if there are two ways seen.

title: Prevent OP engagement when in "Cruise Mode"
body: This is a fix for a safety issue that I discovered by accident in my 2018 Honda Accord.  If I press and hold the ACC following distance button for a number of seconds, the adaptive component of ACC becomes disabled, so the radar is no longer used to control speed.  However, OP works as usual, which seems very dangerous.  This PR fixes that by ensuring that ACC is fully enabled.

title: Chrysler change accel pedal message to avoid false disengage on 2018 Jeeps at low speeds while using ACC.
body:
Verified with multiple cabana drives from users.
Analysis is here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Iu1e4UvAU4c

title: Force steering cut through apply_toyota_steer_torque_limits
body:
If there is a violation do not reduce steering down to 0 in one frame. 

This causes a steering error to occur. 

If the STEER_ERROR_MAX occurs the steering should slowly reduce before the panda registers a violation and also immediately reduces steering torque to 0.

I suggest increasing the panda STEER_ERROR_MAX to 375. This PR will be done in the Panda Repo

title: Openpilot not disengaging with radar issue (GM volt)
body:
I have a 2017 Volt, and in the middle of a drive OP stopped detecting the lead car, but didn't disengage.  I manually disengaged when it became clear that there was an issue.  I was able to operate OP normally, set speed limits etc, but OP would just behave as if there was no lead car.  

Apparently this is related to the radar in the Volt needing to be recalibrated, the fix is to remove the Giraffe and put the ASCM back in and drive around for a bit (in my case 200+ miles) and wait for the stock adaptive cruise control to come back online.

The main issue is that OP didn't disengage or provide any notification that something was wrong.  Stock ACC doesn't allow ACC to be engaged, and provides a notice that says 'ACC temporarily unavailable).  Seems like this could be a safety issue that I wanted to point out, let me know if you need any additional information. Thanks,

Raul
